entry.title: Template: jamie robertson interactive | blog
entry.content:
<data:blog.pageTitle/> */ /* Use this with templates/template-twocol.html */ body { background:$bgcolor; margin:0; color:$textcolor; font:x-small Georgia Serif; font-size/* */:/**/small; font-size: /**/small; text-align: center; } a:link { color:$linkcolor; text-decoration:none; } a:visited { color:$visitedlinkcolor; text-decoration:none; } a:hover { color:$titlecolor; text-decoration:underline; } a img { border-width:0; } /* Header ----------------------------------------------- */ #header-wrapper { margin:0 2% 10px; border:1px solid $bordercolor; } #header { margin: 5px; border: 1px solid $bordercolor; text-align: center; color:$pagetitlecolor; } #header-inner { background-position: center; margin-$startSide: auto; margin-$endSide: auto; } #header h1 { margin:5px 5px 0; padding:15px 20px .25em; line-height:1.2em; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.2em; font: $pagetitlefont; } #header a { color:$pagetitlecolor; text-decoration:none; } #header a:hover { color:$pagetitlecolor; } #header .description { margin:0 5px 5px; padding:0 20px 15px; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.2em; line-height: 1.4em; font: $descriptionfont; color: $descriptioncolor; } #header img { margin-$startSide: auto; margin-$endSide: auto; } /* Outer-Wrapper ----------------------------------------------- */ #outer-wrapper { margin:0; padding:10px; text-align:$startSide; font: $bodyfont; } #main-wrapper { margin-$startSide: 2%; width: 67%; float: $startSide; display: inline; /* fix for doubling margin in IE */ word-wrap: break-word; /* fix for long text breaking sidebar float in IE */ overflow: hidden; /* fix for long non-text content breaking IE sidebar float */ } #sidebar-wrapper { margin-$endSide: 2%; width: 25%; float: $endSide; display: inline; /* fix for doubling margin in IE */ word-wrap: break-word; /* fix for long text breaking sidebar float in IE */ overflow: hidden; /* fix for long non-text content breaking IE sidebar float */ } /* Headings ----------------------------------------------- */ h2 { margin:1.5em 0 .75em; font:$headerfont; line-height: 1.4em; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.2em; color:$sidebarcolor; } /* Posts ----------------------------------------------- */ h2.date-header { margin:1.5em 0 .5em; } .post { margin:.5em 0 1.5em; border-bottom:1px dotted $bordercolor; padding-bottom:1.5em; } .post h3 { margin:.25em 0 0; padding:0 0 4px; font-size:140%; font-weight:normal; line-height:1.4em; color:$titlecolor; } .post h3 a, .post h3 a:visited, .post h3 strong { display:block; text-decoration:none; color:$titlecolor; font-weight:normal; } .post h3 strong, .post h3 a:hover { color:$textcolor; } .post-body { margin:0 0 .75em; line-height:1.6em; } .post-body blockquote { line-height:1.3em; } .post-footer { margin: .75em 0; color:$sidebarcolor; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.1em; font: $postfooterfont; line-height: 1.4em; } .comment-link { margin-$startSide:.6em; } .post img, table.tr-caption-container { padding:4px; border:1px solid $bordercolor; } .tr-caption-container img { border: none; padding: 0; } .post blockquote { margin:1em 20px; } .post blockquote p { margin:.75em 0; } /* Comments ----------------------------------------------- */ #comments h4 { margin:1em 0; font-weight: bold; line-height: 1.4em; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.2em; color: $sidebarcolor; } #comments-block { margin:1em 0 1.5em; line-height:1.6em; } #comments-block .comment-author { margin:.5em 0; } #comments-block .comment-body { margin:.25em 0 0; } #comments-block .comment-footer { margin:-.25em 0 2em; line-height: 1.4em; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.1em; } #comments-block .comment-body p { margin:0 0 .75em; } .deleted-comment { font-style:italic; color:gray; } .feed-links { clear: both; line-height: 2.5em; } #blog-pager-newer-link { float: $startSide; } #blog-pager-older-link { float: $endSide; } #blog-pager { text-align: center; } /* Sidebar Content ----------------------------------------------- */ .sidebar { color: $sidebartextcolor; line-height: 1.5em; } .sidebar ul { list-style:none; margin:0 0 0; padding:0 0 0; } .sidebar li { margin:0; padding-top:0; padding-$endSide:0; padding-bottom:.25em; padding-$startSide:15px; text-indent:-15px; line-height:1.5em; } .sidebar .widget, .main .widget { border-bottom:1px dotted $bordercolor; margin:0 0 1.5em; padding:0 0 1.5em; } #sidebar #LinkList1 a, #sidebar #Text1 a { color: #111111; } .main .Blog { border-bottom-width: 0; } /* Profile ----------------------------------------------- */ .profile-img { float: $startSide; margin-top: 0; margin-$endSide: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px; margin-$startSide: 0; padding: 4px; border: 1px solid $bordercolor; } .profile-data { margin:0; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.1em; font: $postfooterfont; color: $sidebarcolor; font-weight: bold; line-height: 1.6em; } .profile-datablock { margin:.5em 0 .5em; } .profile-textblock { margin: 0.5em 0; line-height: 1.6em; } .profile-link { font: $postfooterfont; text-transform: uppercase; letter-spacing: .1em; } /* Footer ----------------------------------------------- */ #footer { width:660px; clear:both; margin:0 auto; padding-top:15px; line-height: 1.6em; text-transform:uppercase; letter-spacing:.1em; text-align: center; } ]]> <script type="text/javascript"> function setAttributeOnload(object, attribute, val) { if(window.addEventListener) { window.addEventListener('load', function(){ object[attribute] = val; entry.title: Notting Hill Carnival 2012 App- Second Draft- developing for phone gap and testing dimensions on iphone
entry.content:
This is a prototype running in a special browser that allows for full screen on the iphone 4. There are two sizes for each icon / logo / background by using image@2x.png syntax. I will develop this further using phone gap.

See it at:

www.jamierobertsoninteractive.com/dev-phone-prototype

link.title: Notting Hill Carnival 2012 App- Second Draft- developing for phone gap and testing dimensions on iphone

entry.title: HIV charities & advertising approach
entry.content:
New advert for The Topsy Foundation by Ogilvy Johannesburg who had this to say:

"Working together with Topsy, we located Selinah when she was in the very advanced stages of AIDS. We started her on treatment and filmed her every day for 90 days. The transformation is absolutely real. We used no special techniques and tricks in post production. Selinah was brought back to life purely by ARVs and her will to live."




Another ad for an aids charity/awareness by Jonathan Glazer:

entry.title: morph london animation attempt
entry.content: I tried to make an animation for a morph london competition. Morph london is a advertising agency that ran a competition to design a 12 second ident for their logo, which looks a bit like the sculpture above. My idea was to take 60 photos of the clay sculpture as I slowly messed it up into a ball of sloppy clay. I would then edit the photos in back to front order 6 frames per second and jazz it up slightly on after effects so that the logo morphed out of a sloppy mess. I couldnt complete it in time because the clay was impossible to work with (damn gravity) and I had to go to D&AD the next day. Oh well, it was a nice idea.

entry.title: Turn Me On!
entry.content: I've been working on this for ages- since the 19th April, I thought I would have it done in half a week but I couldn't get it right for ages, tried to write some copy for it but ended up sounding too rapey.

entry.title: Garlic & Sapphires Book Cover
entry.content:
The front cover of a book I edited called 'Garlic and Sapphires' (to be published through 'Blurb.com'). The cover is composed of small triangular details of each illustration inside. The book is 128 pages long and showcases the outcomes of a series of collaborative projects between Edinburgh College of Art's Illustration department and Edinburgh University's creative writers. In total there are 49 pieces of creative writing paired with 49 illustrations (I have two illustrations in it). Editing it has been a grueling process but it looks fantastic now its finished and it is available to buy online at Blurb.com.

You can preview it at blurb.com here:

http://www.blurb.com/books/1405940

entry.title: A Riot of Underwear
entry.content: My submission for a project set by Edinburgh's 'Owl & Lion Gallery'. The brief was to illustrate a new collective noun, from all-sorts.org (http://all-sorts.org/nouns). The collective noun I chose was, 'A Riot of Underwear', it was my favourite, and inspired this piece of work.

entry.title: Fish & Shivs
3 page flyer for interior design partnership
entry.content:
.
A 3 page promotional flyer for an interior design partnership called, 'Robertson & Stevens'.



The front of the flyer.



The flyer opened once, revealing the ad copy, price quote, contact details & a sample board.



The flyer fully opened, revealing a double page spread photo of an interior they designed. The sample board features photos of textiles and finishings used for this particular job.

link.title: 3 page flyer for interior design partnership

entry.title: Sketch of British Museum's crowned head sculpture
entry.content: A sketch, on a piece of lino, of a piece of sculpture I saw when I visited the British Museum, to see the 'Kingdom of Ife' exhibition. The piece of sculpture is called, 'Crowned head', from the Wunmonije Compound, Ife, Nigeria, (Yoruba) made between 12th- 14th century C.E., made of copper alloy, 35cm tall. The piece actually has holes pierced through the copper around the mouth and jawline, where it is said that hair would have originally put through, so that the head would have facial hair. I like this idea and wanted to see what the sculpture would look like with a beard.

link.title: Sketch of British Museum's crowned head sculpture

entry.title: Resistance (a 'Don't Panic' poster)
entry.content: My entry into a d&ad competition, sponsored by 'don't panic', on the theme of 'Resistance'. The poster deals with themes of globalisation and global communication, and the implications of these relatively new developments. With this poster I hope to spark some kind of dialogue; Will global communication stay free and autonomous? Should attempts to monitor and control the world wide web be resisted? If so, by whom?

entry.title: Ex*site*ment
entry.content:
*new*
I have built a *new* site, 'jamie robertson innit.com, to show my portfolio. After much deliberation I am proud to announce that I have my site up and running once again. The site is built with indexhibit- a great, free, versatile, easy to use platform. Follow the link at the top right of the page to see it. Now I just have to fill its pages with great work.

entry.title: Mid Year Reviews
entry.content: A rare peek at our studio, and look, there's my desk, with my work and sketchbook neatly arranged on it.

entry.title: snow
Happy New Year.
entry.content:
Some promotional greetings cards I made for the new year. (it's a Mahatma Ghandi quote).



I made this version for the 'Owl and Lion' gallery in Edinburgh (http://www.owlandliongallery.com/), to say thanks and partly because I wanted to draw an owl.

entry.title: Happy birthday Ellen.
entry.content: I made this image for my friend's birthday. In the centre is an old radio dial (one from an old radio I have from 1934). The dial is set to Radio 4. The text is a satire of the Timothy Leary quote, 'Turn On, Tune In, Drop Out'.

entry.title: environment stickers for Ed Uni team
entry.content: The result of a recent collaborative project with Edinburgh University's 'Transition' Society. The society aims to make students in Edinburgh reduce their energy bills by showing simple yet effective ways to do so. The copy was written by Matt Ince.

link.title: environment stickers for Ed Uni team

entry.title: collaborative project with years 2, 3 & 4
entry.content:
This week i took part in a collaborative project with five other eca illustrators from years 2, 3 and 4. We made the tableau above. Each person made an image that responded to the theme of our vices and virtues. Mine is the one in the middle (dreamer).



Colour detail of my illustration.



Another wee detail.

entry.title: Wee Group Animation
entry.content: A short animation that uses images collaged from our group illustration. Made on Adobe Flash. (my flatmate says 'Il finito' means 'the the end' in italian).

entry.title: for David ZW
entry.content: For David ZW- a young, wacky, up and coming author. The inspiration for this comes from illlustrators like Super Expresso and Alex Trochut, and 'Died Young Stayed Pretty'- a movie about American underground 70's rock posters, which i saw on Thursday.

entry.title: coloured foxhunt
entry.content: The foxhunt, finally finished, I think.

entry.title: The foxhunt
entry.content: The finished vector outline, soon to be coloured and textured. Inspired by an article about social conflict between city folk and country folk in the U.K.

entry.title: Recently, my eye has been caught by:
entry.content:
This is the logo for the 'forest cafe'. It has recently been painted onto the pavement just a few yards away from the place. I've always liked the forest cafe logo, its wacky, home-made feel suits the organisation perfectly.



Great packaging from 'Pringles', simple idea, really funny.



This is the first time I have seen a bin liner being branded, and it looks good. It reads, 'THE GREEN SACK. Made in Britain from recycled UK farm plastics'.



Some guerilla advertising by 'Motorola', using a technique pioneered by the street artist Moose whereby the surface is cleaned to make a mark. 'Persil' was one of the first brands to employ this ambient medium and they did it well, and it suited the brand perfectly (ie. cleaning), now tons of brands are using this technique for their advertising (probably because the space is free) and a whole advertising company based around this medium has emerged (see www.dirtystreetadvertising.com). Not actually a very good advert by Motorola as it's really vague- even putting a web address below could have helped.

link.title: Recently, my eye has been caught by:

entry.title: Shoe research- The five minute pack
entry.content:
The 'five minute pack'
a pack of postcards designed by Viktor A and I. The postcards are to be completed by random members of the public. The pack acts as research into how people visualise attaching human emotions onto inanimate objects, in this case shoes. The picture above is what would be printed onto the front of the postcard.



Above are four versions of the kind of thing that would be printed on the back of the postcard. Each one attaches an emotion to the shoe; emotionally unstable, sociopathic, clingy or soulless and presents some kind of object to get the ball rolling.



We also made one for kids. The front would be either blue or pink (boys/girls) and carry the joke, the back would be for them to draw on, hopefully we would get a quick laugh and an incredibly imaginative scribble out of them.

link.title: Shoe research- The five minute pack

entry.title: zebra crossing
what I wore today

entry.title: 4 Archetypes of year 8
entry.content: this is a short video i made intended to be looped. it was to accompany a presentation of four archetypes. the four archetypes represented a class of children in a Danish school. we were interviewing them in order to learn about their routine and eating habits for the pharmaceutical company, 'Novo Nordisk'. i sliced and recycled all the footage in after effects.

entry.title: ayer
entry.content: The first piece of work ive done for the Danmarks Designskole. a one day project called 'manana' to choose any spanish word and illustrate it using everyday objects. Because the title of the brief was 'manana' (english- 'tomorrow'- the deadline was 13.00 the following day) i thought it would be funny to illustrate the word ayer- 'yesterday' with that days news, because by the time i presented the piece, it would have been made with yesterdays news. At the bottom-right corner is the date from the front page of the newspaper, it reads, 'TIRSDAG 2 SEPTEMBER 2008- 8 ARGANG- UGE 36- NR. 150'.

entry.title: badges
entry.content: Six faces, loosely based on people ive seen in Edinburgh. I made wee badges from these images.

entry.title: venue studios
entry.content: from the 26th of March till the 4th April I was commissioned to do this mural for the new venue studios, currently under construction. The tagline reads, 'the creative beat in the heart of edinburgh'. The mural was roughly 2.5m high and 16m wide. Had to kneel on a wheely bin to get to the top, great fun though.

im getting old. I can see the wrinkles on the horizon, its very depressing and its only a matter of time now. but all is not lost!, act now and you still might have a chance, use the mr.robertson, 'give yourself a facelift kit' and turn that frown upside down into a creepy smile. the facelift kit has been kindly modelled on an older, balder me. and look how happy i look. this was for illustration friday, and is my first major venture into digital drawing.

entry.title: logo competition
entry.content: my entry for the eca competition to design a logo for the, 'vacancies/opportunities for eca students and graduates' link on the eportal. thought id shorten the message. of course its not gonna win but i thought the idea was funny. thanks be to alphonse mucha, good job man.
the logo is made from human hair, my human hair (from my head). interesting wee fact.
